Engineering detail. You actually want the parity check to ensure the total number of ones is odd. That way if a wire snaps, and you get all 0's, that's an error. If a wire shorts, and you get all 1's, that's also an error.

what is immediately interesting is

247 message bits
256 128 64 32 16 8 4 2 1 | 9 redundancy bits

one idea to notice mistakes is to have the 9 redundancy bits be a sum of the 0s and 1s of the 247 message bits

a 3 would be 000000011 at the end

I will note that as in the introduction this is similar, it is possible to detect mistakes, altough there's problems if one 1 becomes 0 and one 0 becomes 1, sum will be left as it was, and it's not possible to detect the location

9 is also the amount of 3x3 or 3x2 squares that is there
3x3, 3x3, 3x2
3x3, 3x3, 3x2
3x3, 3x3, 3x2 (3:44)

There is a fairly widely-used archive system called "Parity Archive" that creates .PAR files. When you create these parity files, you specify how much redundancy you want for your data. So for 100 MBytes, you might choose 10% parity. This will give you 10 MBytes of parity data. Now the really neat thing about this is that you can lose UP TO 10 MBytes of your original data, in ANY COMBINATION, and still get that data back from the uncorrupted data combined with the parity set. Very useful for long-term storage applications, given the degradation of magnetic media and even optical disk dyes.

Eric Weinstein turned me on to your videos as part of a bit on the curse of being a visual thinker in a world of symbolic elitism. I'm a highly visual thinker and I've noticed this most of my life. The symbolic elitism of maths, in particular, is woefully evident on Wikipedia, and I shudder to think how many highly intelligent people think themselves useless at maths because the standard pedagogy is so maximally opaque.

Richard Feynman shared both this condition of thinking visually and an intense dislike for said elitism. In one of his lectures, on the wave mechanics of light reflection in terms of phases, he talked for about 10 minutes solid about a mathematical description based on complex numbers - without ONCE uttering the phrase "complex number".

I think his dislike for this state of affairs is one of the reasons for his (sometimes overdone) "everyman" facade and his pride in elegant solutions to problems, because such solutions often constituted an end run around the pedestrian symbolic orthodoxy of science.

Your videos continue this fine and important tradition and allowing visual thinkers to access their full intelligence. The spirit of Feynman lives on in you. Bless you.

This is advanced binary math. But it is fascinating because the implication of these math are really useful, not just an adult trying to impress people with useless games.

Somebody was asking are to read 11 bit here, write 15 bit there.
You use functions already written which accept the size in bit.
For example, binmemcpy(source, destination, size)
But the address source is expressed in binary bit instead of bytes.
So, suppose I copy 13 bit in an array. The starting address is zero, but the address where will be copied the following bits will be:
Byte : 1, bit 5
The next call, binmemcpy(source, 13, ...)
Meaning, take the bit from the source, copy starting at binary location 13...
We know 13 has to become byte 1, bit 5. How do we computer that?
Let say bindesti = 13
ByteAddress = bindesti >> 3
BitDesti = bindesti & 0x07
Let's check if that work.
BinDesti in hexadecimal is 0x0D
In binary, 00001101
Notice the 3 bit to the right, D2-D0=0b101 which is 5
Brief, bit D2-D0 contain the bit position and all other bit are the actual memory address in byte.

Ok I puased at 3:20 and gave it go here's what I came up with (I don't think it's what he'll say, but if it is this would be a waste of time to write out):
TL;DR I managed to get it down to 16bits, but I haven't fully figured out how the 16bits check themselves without impossible assignments

Let's arrange all the bits in a square grid. If there are an even number of 1's in a row we assign it a 1. Otherwise it's assigned a 0. Do the same for the columns. If one bit is changed and we assign 1's and 0's to the rows and columns again, one row and one column will be changed too so now we know the changed bit's coordinates on the grid! For 256 bits, we would need 2(256)^.5=32 bits. This isn't efficient enough, but we can do better.
If we arrange the bits in a cube the same logic will apply, but we assign 1's and 0's to a square layer instead of a row. For 256 bits we would need 3(256)^.(1/3)=19.04--should have remembered 256 isn't cubic--88... Ok so you can't use a cube for 256, but instead of a cube we can have a 4x8x8 prism which would require 4+8+8=20bits which is improvement!
Now let's skip a couple dimensions to an 8 dimensional hyper cube. For 256 bits we would need 8(256)^(1/8)=16bits No!!! I was really banking on that being 8bits. Funny enough 4(256) ^(1/4)=16 so the skip didn't save any data!
I know I haven't wrapped it up (there's some interesting issues when trying to incorporate the redundant bits into the rest), but I gotta watch the rest of the video (and sleep) eventually! If someone bothers to read all of this, thank you! Let me know what you think of this!

You can do like what harddrives do in RAID. Checksum plus parity bits. Parity for each row and checksum (checksum is for each column individually. No parity data is on any other column.) for each column (the parity value should change column for each sequential row in a deterministic fashion). That way you can know that there is a problem and what the problem bit is. It should be resilient as long as you have > n/2 columns of data still available.

this is the code in js if you want to test it, and it's very short actually

it will find and correct if there is 1 error, and say if there are 2 errors.

function Hamming(message) {
const error = parseInt(message.split("").map((a, b, c) => a == "0" ? Array((c.length - 1).toString(2).length).fill("0").join("") : (Array((c.length - 1).toString(2).length).fill("0").join("") + b.toString(2)).slice(-Math.floor(Math.log2(c.length)))).reduce((a, b) => a.split("").map((c, d) => (Number(b[d]) + Number(c)) % 2).join("")), 2)
const parity = message.split("").reduce((a, b) => (Number(a) + Number(b)) % 2)

if (parity == 1) return message.split("").map((a, b) => b == error ? 1 - a : a).join("")
if (error == 0) return message
return "2 errors"
}

About how elegant the solution is. I'll admit that I can be weird, but I don't like when people say computers work in 1s and 0s, or that binary is just about numbers. If you ask me, a bit is really a fundamental unit of measurement: the unit of Information. What is a bit? I'd say it's not a 1 or 0, but rather than a bit should be defined as the answer to a yes or no question. When framed like this, the elegance of the solution becomes obvious. You have 16 cells, which can be addressed by 4 bits. Rather than treat the index of each cell as an opaque number, treat it like 4 yes-or-no questions. What are those questions? They were right there in the video! They're exactly the 4 questions that were used to narrow down where the error was. From this perspective, those 4 questions are what define a 4 bit number. Related to this is the Hamming distance, which is the minimum number of errors that will transform one valid message into another valid message. You can always detect any number of errors less than the Hamming distance, and if the number of errors is less than half the Hamming distance, you can correct the message to the nearest valid message.

Using no error correction the Hamming distance is 1. Using a parity bit the Hamming distance is 2. Using the Hamming Code the Hamming distance is 3. And using the Extended Hamming Code the Hamming distance is 4.

Using the Extended Hamming Code, a single error produces an invalid message adjacent to only a single valid message, allowing you to correct it. Two errors produces an invalid message that is right in between multiple valid messages, letting you know something went wrong but not how to fix it. Three errors can produce an invalid message that is adjacent to the wrong valid message, but it's incredibly unlikely that you have so many errors that you'll see three within the same 16 bit block of data.

It's kinda like a math trick I played before. So the trick was to have N cards, and 2^N-1 numbers are chosen.
For each card, card 2 for example, we have all the numbers below 2^N-1 that its binary digit with value 2 is 1,
i.e. 2,3,6,7,10,11 etc. and do it for all cards. And then, we ask a person to think of a number below 2^N-1 and show us which cards have that number, e.g. for 42, the cards 2,4,6 have 42, since (42)_2=101010. After that, we add up all the respective number of the cards that the person has pointed out (respective number = 2^{{card no.}}), and we get the number! (2+8+32=42 in this example)

I've watched up to 2:10. After the chessboard problem, the one error version of this problem is basically the same solution. Assign each bit to the elements of the finite field GF(256), which takes 8 bits. Then add them all up and that's your hamming code. Subtracting the final sum (after the bit flip) from the hamming code should give zero and if it doesn't, the answer is the flipped bit.

For the two bit version, let the final 9th bit be a parity bit (set it equal to the parity of the block). If the parity bit doesn't match then there was one error. If the parity bit matches but the 8 bit error code says there was an error then there must be two errors.

There's just one more thing. In a finite field, there is an identity element. If that gets flipped, the 8 bit error correcting code will say there is no error, but the parity bit will say there was an error. Well there is only one possibility. (So the 8 bit version doesn't quite work for detecting one error, but 255/256 isn't bad).

Great video as always! This whole "parity check" algorithm reminds me of my favourite puzzle about 1000 barrels of wine. I'll write it here if someone wants to try solving it:

You are a wealthy king of a prosperous, medieval, absolute monarchy. Your daughter is getting married in 11 days (in the morning on the 12-th day from today). Understandably, to celebrate the occasion you organise a lavish wedding party. The main highlight of the planned event is 1000 kegs of the finest wine from overseas that you ordered. They arrived yesterday and you have been bragging about it to everyone who would listen.

Unfortunately, your spies inform you that your enemies secretly added poison to one of the kegs. The poison is so potent, that but a drop can easily kill a man. However, to avoid suspicion, the substance was chosen carefully. It doesn't kill instantly - you die after a week (on the 8-th day), showing no symptoms until then.

Obviously you need to find and get rid of the poisoned keg before the wedding. Moreover, you absolutely can't waste more than 1 keg. You are certainly wealthy enough to afford a whole new batch, but it would certainly not arrive on time. Additionally, if more than 1 keg is missing, someone might notice - it would be a major hit to your prestige, position and rule - after all, as a ruller, perception is everything.

Fortunately, 10 criminals are being held in your dungeon for different crimes pending trial before you. Being a king you can do whatever you want with them - pardon them, kill them or... make them taste the wine.

Your task is simple - you need to find the poisoned keg before the wedding day, but how?
===========================================================================================

TL;DR - 1000 kegs, 1 poisoned. The poison kills on the 8-th day after ingestion. You have 10 prisoners you can force the wine upon. You need to find the poisoned keg in 11 days.

FAQ:
-> A poisoned person dies on the 8-th day but NOT TO THE MINUTE. It could be after 7d + 1h or 7d+14h, you don't know.
-> There is no way to distinguish the poisoned wine from the normal wine. They smell, look, behave exactly the same.
-> You have only 11 days "to work with" - you can't f.ex. check the state of prisoners on the 12-th day, the mystery must solved by then.
-> There is no antidote for the poison.
-> The answer is an algorithm to solve the problem. It's not something along the lines of "I ask the mage, and he divines it" or "I cancel the party"
-> From what I hear there is more than one way to solve it, however I only arrived at a single solution

You can intuitively see how this works when you think about the information required to describe the error. Given a block of 15 bits, there are exactly 16 possible ways to describe a single bit of error (plus no error). That requires 2^4 possible states, which is 4 bits. So it makes perfect sense that 4 bits can account for the error in a block of 15, and this pattern extends to any arbitrary power of 2.

Had the idea of using the solution to the chess board riddle from one of your recent videos to detect single errors. The square of bits encoding the information is like the square of head/tail coins on the chess board. Like in the riddle, this board encodes a certain position to be where the "key" is, and using the method explained in the solution to the riddle to locate the key position from the board layout, we would know if there is an error or not by making sure if the supposed "key" of the board layout is where it should be. If its not, well we know there was an error, and supposing its only a single error, we can track it down by reversing the riddle solution algorithm to find the bit we have to flip to have the "key" back in its original postion. If you think about it, it would take log base 2 of n amount of redundant bits to mark the location of the key, so a similar amount of redundant bits needed as the hamming code. I guess things get complicated if those redundant bits are where the error is though. Just some food for thought

The questions are based on which indices have a 1 in the same position it's in in the parity bit. This is why the parity bits are the powers of two, as they have a single 1 in them. This can also be seen as which indices, when passed with the parity index through a bitwise and, do not return 0. This bitwise and allows it to be so simple to program.

You can roll that extra parity bit implicltly into the calculations for the hamming code. When you do that, for 16 bits of parity and data, you get a 5-bit error position. If there is a one-bit error, you'll compute an error position between 0-15. If there is no error, you'll compute a 16. If there is a 2-bit error, you'll compute an error position 17-31.

If you know of some clever way to encode your message as a grid where each row, column, and 3*3 has every digit 1-9, you can remove/edit a bunch of them and only need a few to find the original message. And, in a similar way, you're checking the "completeness" of each group and using it to fill in the missing info.
